metadata.title: Complete Stanford Law Review Redbook Rules Analysis
metadata.description: Comprehensive analysis of all 115 Redbook rules with error detection patterns, validation prompts, and examples
critical_corrections: RB 1.12: REQUIRES explanatory parentheticals with 'see generally' and 'cf.' (CORRECTED - original text incorrectly stated 'Do not include')
metadata.notes: Redbook rules OVERRIDE Bluebook for Stanford Law Review. This analysis provides 200+ error detection patterns.

rule_sections.1: Structure and Use of Citations (16 rules)
rule_sections.9: Titles of Judges, Officials, Terms of Court (3 rules)
rule_sections.24: Additional Stylistic and Grammatical Rules (11 rules)

rules.title: Quoting and Citing Parentheticals
rules.full_text:
SLR always requires a (quoting . . .) parenthetical when quoted material itself quotes another source. If the author has forgotten to include a quoting parenthetical, you are responsible for adding one yourself and conducting all the sourcepulling, citechecking, and bluebooking required.

“This is a sentence from X that ‘quotes from another source Y.’” X (quoting Y).

SLR never requires a (citing . . .) parenthetical. But authors may elect to do so. Do not delete them.

For quoting and citing parentheticals, you are responsible for citechecking the quoted or cited source just as if the author had cited it directly.

error_types.name: Missing quoting parenthetical
error_types.description: Quoted text contains internal quotes but lacks (quoting...) parenthetical
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check if this quoted text contains internal quotation marks. If it does, verify that a (quoting...) parenthetical follows. Text: {{text}}

incorrect:
"The Court noted 'with all deliberate speed' in its ruling."1
1. Brown v. Board, 349 U.S. 294, 301 (1955).
correct:
"The Court noted 'with all deliberate speed' in its ruling."1
1. Brown v. Board, 349 U.S. 294, 301 (1955) (quoting earlier precedent).

error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Missing (quoting...) parenthetical - quoted text contains internal quotes

error_types.name: Uncitechecked quoting source
error_types.description: Source in (quoting...) parenthetical not fully citechecked
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Verify the source in the (quoting...) parenthetical has been fully citechecked. Text: {{text}}

rules.title: Identifying References (Drop Citations)
rules.full_text:
When a citation is used solely to identify a particular authority—rather than to support a factual or legal proposition—the footnote call number should appear immediately after the source (and after any punctuation mark except for a dash or colon, see BB 1.1(a)), in the text.

Justice Brandeis never knew about Brown v. Board of Education1 or Between the World and Me;2 both were written after he died.

1. 347 U.S. 483 (1954).
2. TA-NEHISI COATES, BETWEEN THE WORLD AND ME (2015).

Note: When a source is introduced in a sentence but also supports its proposition, this rule does not apply. Include only a single footnote with the call number where it would otherwise appear. However, this rule interacts with RB 1.4 if the source supports only part of a sentence. In these situations, leave an [SE:] Comment and a note in the master spreadsheet suggesting a rewrite.

error_types.name: Identifying References (Drop Citations) violation
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 1.2: Identifying References (Drop Citations). Key requirements: prohibited action, recommended action. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Verify compliance with RB 1.2: Identifying References (Drop Citations)

error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check formatting compliance with RB 1.2. Text: {{text}}

error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check for consistent application of RB 1.2 throughout document. Text: {{text}}

rules.title: Cases Named in Text
rules.full_text:
If a footnote supports text that names the case cited, the case name need not be repeated in the footnote, so long as the case name used in the text would be sufficient for the type of citation (long or short-form) required in the corresponding footnote. See BB 10.9; see also RB 10.9.

Thus, if a case is named in the text but has not been cited within the preceding five footnotes, the case must either be spelled out (1) in full in the text and omitted from the footnote or (2) in short in the text and in full in the footnote.

rules.title: Footnote Call Number Placement
rules.full_text:
SLR deviates from BB 1.1 in placing footnote call numbers at the end of a sentence if the source cited supports only part of the sentence.

The police were unable to obtain a warrant, but discovered the evidence in plain view.3

3. See California v. Ciraolo, 476 U.S. 207, 213 (1986) (explaining the plain-view doctrine).

In this example, the citation supports only the second clause of the sentence. Under SLR’s rule, the footnote call number goes at the end of the sentence (after the period) rather than after “plain view.”

A similar rule applies when the source supports only one of multiple independent clauses separated by semicolons (or em dashes). Place the footnote call number at the end of the entire sentence, after the period. But if the sources are in the same clause, the footnote call number is placed at the end of the clause (before the semicolon).

error_types.name: Footnote placed mid-sentence for partial support
error_types.description: Footnote in middle of sentence when should be at end (SLR deviation from Bluebook)
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check if citation supports only part of sentence. Under SLR rules (RB 1.4), footnote should go at END of sentence, not mid-sentence. This is DIFFERENT from Bluebook. Text: {{text}}

incorrect: The police were unable to obtain a warrant, but discovered the evidence in plain view.3
correct: The police were unable to obtain a warrant, but discovered the evidence in plain view.3

error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Move footnote to end of sentence per RB 1.4 (SLR deviation from BB 1.1)

rules.title: Multiple Sources Following Compare and Contrast
rules.full_text:
When using compare and contrast signals, separate multiple sources with semicolons. Do not use commas to separate them. See BB 1.2; cf. BB 1.3.

Compare Roe v. Wade, 410 U.S. 113 (1973), with Doe v. Bolton, 410 U.S. 179 (1973); compare Brown v. Bd. of Educ., 347 U.S. 483 (1954), with Plessy v. Ferguson, 163 U.S. 537 (1896).

✶ ✶ ✶

✶ Note that multiple sources following other signals are separated by commas (e.g., See X, Y, and Z). This rule applies only when using compare/contrast signals.

rules.title: Multiple Sources Following a Signal as a Verb
rules.full_text:
When a signal is used as a verb (e.g., “But see X” as opposed to “But see X, Y, and Z”), separate multiple sources with semicolons. See BB 1.2, 1.3.

But see Roe v. Wade, 410 U.S. 113 (1973); Doe v. Bolton, 410 U.S. 179 (1973).

✶ ✶ ✶

✶ Multiple sources following other signals as verbs (e.g., See also X, Y, and Z) are separated by commas. This rule applies only when using signals as verbs.

rules.title: When a Source Quotes or Cites Multiple Sources
rules.full_text:
If an author cites a source that, in turn, quotes or cites multiple other sources, avoid citing through to the underlying sources. Just cite the source that the author cited or quoted.

Quote: The Court noted “that [the death] penalty is an unusually severe and degrading punishment,” Trop v. Dulles, 356 U.S. 86, 99 (1958), but it ultimately upheld the punishment.

Article: The Court noted “that [the death] penalty is an unusually severe and degrading punishment,” but it ultimately upheld the punishment.44

44. Trop v. Dulles, 356 U.S. 86, 99 (1958).

As shown in this example, the author quoted a sentence from Trop v. Dulles that itself quoted the “unusually severe and degrading” language from another source. The author could have cited Trop’s underlying source, but didn’t. That’s fine — and you should not add a citation to the underlying source. Just keep the Trop citation.

rules.title: Preferred Sources and Quoting or Citing Parentheticals
rules.full_text:
When possible, quote or cite from the source that SLR prefers (as identified in RB 15.5), even when the author has not used SLR’s preferred source.

For example, if an author quotes from THE FEDERALIST NO. 10, and the quote appears in multiple editions, SLR has preferred sources. See, e.g., RB 15.5. If the piece you are editing cites or quotes a nonpreferred edition, find the quote in SLR’s preferred edition and switch to that edition.

If SLR has no preference, however, leave the author’s choice alone.

rules.title: Nested Parentheticals
rules.full_text:
Do not use nested parentheses inside a parenthetical. If you need to include a parenthetical within a parenthetical, change the inner parentheses to square brackets.

Wrong: (citing (for example, the Hippocratic Oath)).
Right: (citing [for example, the Hippocratic Oath]).

rules.title: Length of Explanatory Parentheticals
rules.full_text:
Try to keep explanatory parentheticals short (generally, under fifty words). Explanatory parentheticals usually merely provide an example, explanation, or parenthetical quotation. If a thought is lengthy, consider breaking it out into its own sentence.

Note: Per BB 1.5, a parenthetical phrase that is grammatically part of a sentence (rather than an example, explanation, or quote) is not preceded by an em dash.

✶ ✶ ✶

✶ If an explanatory parenthetical is over fifty words, consider suggesting in an [SE:] Comment that the author shorten it or make it its own sentence.

rules.title: Grammar of Explanatory Parentheticals
rules.full_text:
Explanatory parentheticals must start with a present participle, a quoted sentence, or a short quotation: “(arguing that . . .)”, “(“They started on a campaign of harassment.”)”, or “(“start[ing] on a campaign of harassment” [emphasis added])”. See BB 1.5.

They should never start with a capital letter (unless the first word is a proper noun), a direct quote that is a full sentence (i.e., beginning with a capital letter and ending with a period), or a parenthetical letter. They should also never start with a present participle that doesn’t agree with the subject of the main sentence, a main verb, or an article (a, an, the).

If it’s unclear whether a present participle agrees with the subject, you have a couple options. Often, you can add a few words to clarify the participle’s meaning. Alternatively, consider leaving an [SE:] Comment suggesting a rewrite. (If you do leave a comment, be sure to also note the issue in the master spreadsheet.)

rules.title: Explanatory Parentheticals with See Generally and Cf. Citations
rules.full_text: CORRECTED: SLR REQUIRES explanatory parentheticals for sources following 'See generally' or 'Cf.' signals. These signals indicate an extremely general or clearly analogous proposition, respectively. An explanatory parenthetical is REQUIRED to explain the connection.

error_types.name: Missing parenthetical with 'see generally'
error_types.description: 'See generally' citation lacks REQUIRED explanatory parenthetical
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: CRITICAL: Check if 'see generally' citation has explanatory parenthetical. Per RB 1.12, this is REQUIRED (not optional). Text: {{text}}

incorrect: See generally Smith v. Jones, 123 F.3d 456 (9th Cir. 2020).
correct: See generally Smith v. Jones, 123 F.3d 456 (9th Cir. 2020) (providing background on the doctrine).

error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Add REQUIRED explanatory parenthetical for 'see generally' per RB 1.12

error_types.name: Missing parenthetical with 'cf.'
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: CRITICAL: Check if 'cf.' citation has explanatory parenthetical. Per RB 1.12, this is REQUIRED to explain the analogy. Text: {{text}}

incorrect: Cf. Smith v. Jones, 123 F.3d 456 (9th Cir. 2020).
correct: Cf. Smith v. Jones, 123 F.3d 456 (9th Cir. 2020) (applying similar reasoning).

error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Add REQUIRED explanatory parenthetical for 'cf.' per RB 1.12

rules.critical_correction: ORIGINAL TEXT WAS INCORRECT. It said 'Do not include' but should say 'REQUIRES'. This has been corrected in the error patterns above.

rules.title: Parentheticals Indicating Alterations to Emphasis and Capitalization
rules.full_text:
When indicating altered capitalization or added emphasis in a quote, use a single parenthetical that covers both. Specifically, use “(alteration in original)” or “(emphasis added)”, not “(capitalization altered)” or “(alteration and emphasis in original)”. See BB 5.2.

SLR deviates from BB 5.2 in that if both capitalization and emphasis have been altered in a quote, you should still just write “(alteration in original)” or “(emphasis added)”. Do not use “(alteration and emphasis added)” or “(alteration and emphasis in original)”.

SLR is more concerned with substance than form, so don’t fret if an author doesn’t note an added emphasis or altered capitalization. Just leave it be.

SLR is less concerned with Bluebook perfection than it is with content accuracy and consistency. If an author adds emphasis in a quote without noting it, or if an author alters capitalization in a quote, do not bother adding a parenthetical. It is not our job to edit on a micro-level — or to “Bluebook” a piece — with such intensity. That said, if something in the quote really seems off, leave an [SE:] Comment and a note in the master spreadsheet.

rules.title: Added Alterations and Retained Emphasis
rules.full_text: If adding a parenthetical noting an alteration (including added emphasis), make it “(alteration in original)” or “(emphasis added)”, not “(alteration and emphasis added)” or “(alteration and emphasis in original)”. The parenthetical covers both an alteration and added emphasis, if both are present. This rule applies even if the original source itself noted a change in emphasis.

rules.title: Explanatory Parentheticals and In
rules.full_text:
Contrary to BB 1.5(b), BB 1.6(a)(i), and the Rand example in footnote 5 of BB 15.10.1, SLR convention is to place explanatory parentheticals after the collection information (rather than after the “in” phrase introducing the collection). For example:

Jane Doe, Toward a Theory, in GREAT PAPERS 3, 4 (2024) (arguing that . . .).

The Bluebook suggests that the parenthetical explanation belong after “Jane Doe, Toward a Theory,”, before the “in” phrase. But SLR instead places it at the end, as in the above example. If you see an “in”-introductory parenthetical in a citation, shift it to the end.

Note: There is an exception for cases in which the explanatory parenthetical applies to the larger work (rather than to the source within the larger work). For example:

Jane Doe, Toward a Theory, in GREAT PAPERS 3 (John Smith ed., 2024) (collection of essays analyzing . . .).

Here, the explanatory parenthetical applies to Great Papers (the larger work) as a whole, so it belongs before the “in” phrase. But if it applies to the smaller work (Jane Doe’s essay), it belongs at the end of the cite. When in doubt about where the explanatory parenthetical belongs in an “in” citation, just leave an [SE:] Comment. The SE will figure it out.

rules.title: Ordering of Parentheticals
rules.full_text:
When multiple parentheticals follow a citation, their order is: weight of authority parenthetical, explanatory parenthetical, then any parenthetical containing a quotation.

See BB 1.5.

rules.title: Underlined Type
rules.full_text: SLR uses underlining (or italics) only in a small handful of situations, such as some textual case names, book titles, and in certain documents (see, e.g., RB 16.5, 18.7). Do not underline text for emphasis, and do not underline punctuation adjacent to underlined text. See RB 2.3.

rules.title: Bolded Type
rules.full_text:
SLR uses bold text only in Extraordinary Circumstances. Specifically, a Stanford Law Review print piece may use bold in the rare case that the author’s argument explicitly centers around an emphasized word (e.g., a piece about “fair” vs. “free” trade). Bold type is sometimes used for Article titles in citations; you should follow the author’s lead on whether to apply that rule. See BB 16.7.3.

Do not add bold for emphasis in any other circumstances, and remove it if authors add it.

rules.title: Italics and Punctuation
rules.full_text:
Italicize punctuation marks only if they are immediately adjacent to italicized words. If there is a space between an italicized word and a punctuation mark, do not italicize the punctuation mark.

See BB 2.1(d).

rules.title: Naming Internal References
rules.full_text:
The first time an internal cross-reference to a specific part or section of a piece is introduced, that part or section must be named (as in Part I or the Introduction). After that initial naming, subsequent cross-references to that part can use “Part I” or “the Introduction” without clarification. But the first time, always include the name.

Right: This Part (Part I) discusses . . .
Wrong: This Part discusses . . .

Right: the Introduction (describing . . .)
Wrong: the Introduction (Part I) (describing . . .)

Right: Part I (Introduction) discusses . . .
Wrong: Part I discusses . . .

rules.title: Capitalizing Internal References
rules.full_text:
When referring to specific parts of a piece, only capitalize the reference if the reference is specific; do not capitalize if the reference is general.

Right: Part II, Section B, the Introduction
Wrong: the Part, the Section

Right: the next part, a later section
Wrong: the Next Part, a Later Section

rules.title: Footnotes Identified by Symbols
rules.full_text:
When symbols are used to identify footnotes (as in author footnotes on the first page of an Article), the order is: *, †, ‡, §, ¶, **, ††, ‡‡, §§, ¶¶.

See BB 2.1, 2.2.

rules.title: Internal Cross-References
rules.full_text:
Introduce cross-references with an italicized “Part” or “Section” (unless it would introduce confusion). Do not use “Subpart”, “Subsection”, or similar language to refer to parts and sections of the piece; instead, write out the specific Part, Section, etc.

Right: Part I discusses . . . , see Section II.A.
Wrong: Section I.B discusses . . .
Wrong: Subpart I.B discusses . . .

rules.title: Inserting Cross-References
rules.full_text: If you suspect that a cross-reference would be helpful (e.g., if two Parts discuss similar topics), leave an [SE:] Comment for your SE about adding one; do not add it yourself. Use an [SE:] Comment rather than inserting it directly because the author may have made a conscious decision not to include a cross-reference, and the SE may wish to consult with the author before adding one.

rules.title: Pincites
rules.full_text:
Always include a pincite when citing a case, statute, book, or other nonperiodical source, even if citing the source as a whole. Do not, however, include pincites when citing cases in textual sentences. See BB 3.2; BB 10.9.

That is, if you write, “In Roe v. Wade, 410 U.S. 113 (1973), the Court . . .”, don’t include a pincite after 113.

rules.title: Et seq.
rules.full_text: SLR follows BB 3.3 in using “et seq.” only for page ranges longer than three pages (e.g., 240–47) and only in rare circumstances. It should not be used for citations in most SLR pieces.

rules.title: Using Id.
rules.full_text:
If a source has appeared in one of the previous five footnotes, do not use id. if subsequent references are clearly to the same source and footnote. Just use supra. If there is any ambiguity about which source is being referenced, then use id.

See BB 4.1.

rules.title: Id. and Footnotes
rules.full_text:
Do not use id. to refer to a source cited solely in a preceding footnote’s explanatory parenthetical. Use supra instead.

See BB 4.3.

rules.title: Hereinafter
rules.full_text:
Use hereinafter sparingly. Unlike with supra, which should be used for all subsequent references to a source (other than with cases, statutes, etc.), hereinafter should only be used when a supra would be confusing. Hereinafter is most common for sources with very long titles and similar beginnings or multiple sources by the same author in the same year.

Even if the Bluebook would allow a hereinafter, default to using supra for cases in which the potential confusion is minimal.

See BB 4.2.

rules.title: Placement of Punctuation Marks
rules.full_text:
When a punctuation mark is present in the underlying material but not intended to be part of the quotation, the punctuation mark should be omitted if it comes at the end of a quotation and should be included if it comes at the beginning of a quotation.

See BB 5.1.

rules.title: Block Quotes
rules.full_text: SLR follows BB 5.1 in using block quotes for quotations of fifty or more words. As BB 5.1(a) suggests, it is often permissible to avoid a block quote by simply not quoting extraneous language (e.g., starting and ending a quote in the middle of a sentence), and you should do so when possible. But do not rewrite quotes just to avoid block quoting, and do not try to sneak in a forty-nine-word quotation to avoid a block quote when a longer quote would provide essential context.

rules.title: Omissions from Quotations
rules.full_text:
Use an ellipsis ( . . . ) to indicate the omission of one or more words from the middle of a quoted sentence. Do not use an ellipsis at the beginning of a quotation (even if the beginning of the sentence is omitted) or at the end of a quotation (even if the end of the sentence is omitted) unless what follows in the sentence is also omitted. If one or more full sentences are omitted from the quotation, use an ellipsis that includes end punctuation (e.g., “. . . .”). Leave a space before and after each period in the ellipsis. Do not omit punctuation before or after the ellipsis unless it is a comma that serves only to indicate a series of items.

See BB 5.3–5.4.

rules.title: Alterations to Quotations
rules.full_text:
Use brackets to indicate any alterations to the text of a quotation, including altered capitalization, added or changed emphasis, or added footnote call numbers. See RB 1.13; BB 5.2.

Use “[sic]” to indicate any obvious errors or misprints in the original quotation that you cannot correct (but for minor errors, consider paraphrasing instead). Do not use “[sic]” to indicate an alternate but still correct spelling (e.g., alternate spelling of a word ending in “-ize” or “-yze”). See RB 24.1.

rules.title: Textual Citations Within Quotations
rules.full_text:
In general, citations within quotations should be omitted unless particularly relevant.

Original source: The Court specified “with all deliberate speed,” Brown II, 75 S. Ct. at 757, but that phrase is not a model of clarity.

Article: As one commentator noted, “The Court specified ‘with all deliberate speed,’ but that phrase is not a model of clarity.”373

373. Collin Fredricks & Catherina Y. Xu, One Thousand and One Galley Nights, 76 STAN. L. REV. 1789, 1895 (2023) (citation omitted) (quoting Brown v. Bd. of Educ. (Brown II), 349 U.S. 294, 301 (1955)).

If the quoted citation is particularly relevant and must be retained, it should appear as it does in the quoted source—including, unfortunately, any Bluebooking errors.

rules.title: Abbreviating Professional Degrees
rules.full_text: Contrary to CMOS 10.21, SLR does not omit periods in educational degrees. Use “J.D.” instead of “JD” and “Ph.D.” over “PhD” (and so on). Note that we would never include an author’s degree—periods or not—in a citation. See BB 15.1.

rules.title: Other Widely Recognized Initials
rules.full_text:
(a) Below is an expanded list of “widely recognized initials” for the purposes of BB 6.1(b), 10.2.1(c). This list is also incorporated into BB Table T6.

AARP (formerly American Association of Retired Persons)
ACLU (American Civil Liberties Union)
AFL-CIO (American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations)
CBP (Customs and Border Patrol)
CBS (formerly Columbia Broadcasting System)
CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention)
CIA (Central Intelligence Agency)
DCFS (Department of Children & Family Services)
EEOC (Equal Employment Opportunity Commission)
FAA (Federal Aviation Administration)
FBI (Federal Bureau of Investigation)
FCC (Federal Communications Commission)
FDA (Food and Drug Administration)
GAO (Government Accountability Office)
GM (General Motors)
IKEA (named for founder Ingvar Kamprad and hometown Elmtaryd Agunnaryd)
IMF (International Monetary Fund)
IRS (Internal Revenue Service)
LGBT (lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender)
MLB (Major League Baseball)
NAACP (National Association for the Advancement of Colored People)
NASA (National Aeronautics and Space Administration)
NCAA (National Collegiate Athletic Association)
NFL (National Football League)
NLRB (National Labor Relations Board)
NSC (National Security Council)
NYSE (New York Stock Exchange)
PBS (Public Broadcasting Service)
RNC (Republican National Committee)
SSA (Social Security Administration)
UNICEF (United Nations International Children’s Emergency Fund)
USCIS (United States Citizenship and Immigration Services)
VA (Veterans Affairs)

(b) In addition, below is a list of other initialisms that can be used without periods (contrary to BB 6.1(b)).

CLU (Community Legal Services)
COBRA (Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act)
NPRM (Notice of Proposed Rulemaking)
OPM (Office of Personnel Management)
RESTATEMENT (THIRD) OF RESTITUTION (2011) (short form: R3RUE)
RESTATEMENT (THIRD) OF UNFAIR COMPETITION (1995) (short form: R3UC)
SLR (Stanford Law Review)

See BB 6.1(b), 10.2.1(c).

rules.title: Introducing Acronyms and Initialisms
rules.full_text:
If an acronym or initialism is not widely known, write out its full name the first time it is used, followed immediately by the acronym or initialism in parentheses.

Right: the Department of Energy (DOE)
Wrong: the Department of Energy (DOE Department)
Wrong: the Department of Energy

It is also often helpful to remind the reader of an acronym or initialism’s meaning if it hasn’t appeared for a while. In those cases, either reintroduce it parenthetically or note in the text that it refers to the same thing as an earlier acronym or initialism.

See BB 6.1(c).

rules.title: Acronyms vs. Initialisms
rules.full_text: Generally, use an acronym (pronounced as a word, like NASA) rather than an initialism (pronounced as letters, like FBI) for a given name if one exists. For example, it’s better to say “HUD” than “H–U–D” when referring to the Department of Housing and Urban Development. See BB 6.1(c).

rules.full_text: In general, follow BB 6.2 in spelling out numbers zero through ninety-nine in text (100 and above appear as numerals). For other rules on numbers, see CMOS 9.

rules.full_text: Spell out the adjectival form of any geographical abbreviation listed in BB Table T10. For example, do not abbreviate “Californian” as “Cal.”.

rules.title: Abbreviating Hyphenated Words from BB Tables T6, T10, and T13
rules.full_text: Words that appear in BB Tables T6, T10, or T13 should be abbreviated even when part of a hyphenated phrase. For example, “Federal Bureau of Investigation” is abbreviated as “FBI”, and “Counterterrorism and Counterintelligence” is abbreviated as “CT&C” (for “Counterterrorism & Counterintelligence”).

rules.title: Abbreviations for Statutes
rules.full_text: When citing statutes, use only the abbreviations provided in BB Table T1 (or the abbreviations for geographic words in BB Table T10 if needed). Do not abbreviate parts of a statutory name that are not abbreviated in Table T1. In particular, do not use the three-letter abbreviations from Table T6 in a statutory name, even if the statute includes a word like “Commission” or “Association.”

rules.title: Italicizing Foreign Words
rules.full_text:
Italicize words in a foreign language (except for proper nouns, e.g., names of people or organizations) unless they have been incorporated into common English usage. Words that appear in Black’s Law Dictionary or Merriam-Webster do not need to be italicized. Avoid italicizing longer phrases.

See BB 7.1.4.

rules.title: Parts of the Constitution
rules.full_text:
Capitalize references to Articles, Amendments, Clauses, and other subdivisions of the U.S. Constitution, even when used generically. For example, “in several Clauses, the Constitution prohibits . . . .”

See BB 8.

rules.title: Titles of Cited Material: Capitalization and Italicization
rules.full_text:
Follow BB 8–9 and BB 10.2.2 in capitalizing and italicizing (or underlining) the titles of sources.

Note that BB 8 covers which words in a title should be capitalized (short answer: all words except articles, conjunctions, and prepositions of four or fewer letters), and BB 10.2.2 covers which titles should be italicized/underlined (short answer: books, periodicals, and similar noncourt documents — but not provisions of constitutions, restatements, or model codes, and not case names in textual sentences).

rules.title: Headings, Subheadings, and Text
rules.full_text:
SLR’s authors use title-style capitalization for headings and subheadings (meaning that, as stated above, all words are capitalized except articles, conjunctions, and prepositions of four or fewer letters). SLR departs from BB 8 in also using title-style capitalization for text (including the title of the piece and author’s name) that appears on the first page of the piece. Do not “downstyle” any text (e.g., the author’s title or position) that appears on the first page.

See BB 8; BB 9.

rules.title: Ethnic or National Groups
rules.full_text:
Capitalize the names of ethnic or national groups as proper nouns (e.g., Black, Native, Indigenous). This is an exception to CMOS 8.38, which suggests lowercasing “black” and “white” when referring to race, but is in line with SLR’s historical practice.

See BB 8.1(g).

rules.title: Textual References to Professors
rules.section: TITLES OF JUDGES, OFFICIALS, AND TERMS OF COURT
rules.full_text:
In text (as opposed to in citations), SLR omits “Professor” in front of names. For example, if Jane Doe is a professor, refer to her as “Jane Doe”, not “Professor Doe” or “Professor Jane Doe”. But if an author has “Professor” in front of the name in the text, leave it as is.

See BB 15.1; BB 15.2; BB 15.1(c).

rules.title: Textual References to Judges as Authors of Judicial Materials
rules.section: TITLES OF JUDGES, OFFICIALS, AND TERMS OF COURT
rules.full_text:
In text, if a judge is the author of a judicial opinion or other document being discussed, use “Justice” or “Judge” (etc.) before their name.

Right: Justice Sotomayor’s dissent was . . .
Right: Judge Breyer’s opinion was . . .
Wrong: Sotomayor’s dissent was . . .

See BB 15.1; BB 15.2; BB 15.1(c).

rules.title: Judges as Authors in General
rules.section: TITLES OF JUDGES, OFFICIALS, AND TERMS OF COURT
rules.full_text:
In text, if a judge is not the author of the document being discussed, use just the judge’s last name without a title.

Right: Sotomayor joined the majority opinion . . .
Wrong: Justice Sotomayor joined the majority opinion . . .

See BB 15.1; BB 15.2; BB 15.1(c).

error_types.name: Judges as Authors in General violation
error_types.description: See RB 9.3: Judges as Authors in General
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 9.3: Judges as Authors in General. Key requirements: see rule text. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Verify compliance with RB 9.3: Judges as Authors in General

rules.title: Citechecking Cases
rules.full_text:
For each case a piece cites, ensure that the case is still good law. If any negative treatment has since occurred (e.g., overruled, abrogated, superseded), add a parenthetical explaining that. Additionally, verify that the case name and reporter information are accurate. Don’t assume that an author’s citations to commonly cited cases (e.g., Roe v. Wade) are correct; always cross-check.

If a case has been granted cert and is pending before SCOTUS, note in a parenthetical that cert is pending; if a case is pending before a federal en banc panel, note that; etc.

If you aren’t sure whether to flag a case, leave an [SE:] Comment for your SE.

See BB 10.7.1; BB 10.7.2.

error_types.name: Case citation error - Citechecking Cases
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 10.1: Citechecking Cases. Text: {{text}}

rules.title: Terms Clearly Indicating That the Party Is a Business Firm
rules.full_text:
If a business designation (e.g., Inc., LLC) clearly indicates that a party is a business firm, do not add an identifying parenthetical. For example, in “Facebook, Inc. v. Duguid”, do not add “(a technology company)” after “Facebook, Inc.”. But if the party name does not clearly indicate it is a business firm, then add a parenthetical identifying the party.

See BB 10.2.1(h).

error_types.name: Case citation error - Terms Clearly Indicating That the Party Is a Business Firm
error_types.description: See RB 10.2 - Terms Clearly Indicating That the Party Is a Business Firm
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 10.2: Terms Clearly Indicating That the Party Is a Business Firm. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Check RB 10.2 - Terms Clearly Indicating That the Party Is a Business Firm

rules.title: Widely Recognized Initials in Case Names
rules.full_text:
The list of “widely recognized” acronyms and initials in BB 6.1(b) that can be used in case names (BB 10.2.2) is expanded in RB 6.2. In case names, you can use any of those abbreviations.

See BB 10.2.2; RB 6.2.

error_types.name: Case citation error - Widely Recognized Initials in Case Names
error_types.description: See RB 10.3 - Widely Recognized Initials in Case Names
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 10.3: Widely Recognized Initials in Case Names. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Check RB 10.3 - Widely Recognized Initials in Case Names

rules.title: Procedural Phrases in Case Names
rules.full_text: Omit procedural phrases (e.g., “on behalf of”) in case names unless they are needed to distinguish between parties. See BB 10.2.1(f).

error_types.name: Case citation error - Procedural Phrases in Case Names
error_types.description: See RB 10.4 - Procedural Phrases in Case Names
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 10.4: Procedural Phrases in Case Names. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Check RB 10.4 - Procedural Phrases in Case Names

rules.title: Titles of Amicus Curiae Briefs
rules.full_text:
If the title of an amicus brief starts with “Brief for” or “Brief of”, use that full title (including “Brief for/of”) when referencing the brief in a citation. If the title does not start with “Brief for/of”, then insert “Brief for” at the beginning when writing the title in a citation (even though that phrase is not part of the official title).

See BB 10.8.3.

error_types.name: Case citation error - Titles of Amicus Curiae Briefs
error_types.description: See RB 10.5 - Titles of Amicus Curiae Briefs
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 10.5: Titles of Amicus Curiae Briefs. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Check RB 10.5 - Titles of Amicus Curiae Briefs

rules.title: Parallel Citations for Court Filings
rules.full_text:
When citing a specific page of a court filing, always include a parallel citation to the page number of the PDF or ECF (e.g., “at 4, 2021 WL 12345, at *2”). This helps the reader locate the relevant page.

See BB 10.8.3; BB 7.3.2.

error_types.name: Case citation error - Parallel Citations for Court Filings
error_types.description: See RB 10.6 - Parallel Citations for Court Filings
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 10.6: Parallel Citations for Court Filings. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Check RB 10.6 - Parallel Citations for Court Filings

rules.title: Court Filings Before and After a Decision Has Been Rendered
rules.full_text: Do not include a court or decision year for court filings that predate the court’s decision. Include a court and decision year only for filings that postdate the decision (e.g., when citing an appellate brief filed after the lower court’s decision). See BB 10.8.3; BB 10.8.1(a).

error_types.name: Case citation error - Court Filings Before and After a Decision Has Been Rendered
error_types.description: See RB 10.7 - Court Filings Before and After a Decision Has Been Rendered
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 10.7: Court Filings Before and After a Decision Has Been Rendered. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Check RB 10.7 - Court Filings Before and After a Decision Has Been Rendered

rules.title: Weight of Authority
rules.full_text:
Include information about the weight of an authority (e.g., dissenting opinion, en banc decision, plurality opinion, per curiam decision) only if it is relevant to the author’s point.

If an opinion is unpublished (and you are citing it in accordance with BB 10.8.1(a)), you must add a parenthetical indicating that it is a memorandum decision or order (unless it comes from a jurisdiction that issues only unreported decisions).

See BB 10.6.1(f); BB 10.8.1(a).

error_types.name: Case citation error - Weight of Authority
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 10.8: Weight of Authority. Text: {{text}}

rules.title: The Five-Footnote Rule for Short Citations
rules.full_text:
If a case has not been cited within the preceding five footnotes, use a full citation instead of a short form. See BB 10.9.

This rule applies even if an authority is named in the text and even if it was cited fully elsewhere in the same footnote.

error_types.name: Short form outside 5-footnote window
error_types.description: Case cited in short form but not cited in preceding 5 footnotes
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check if case was cited in full within preceding 5 footnotes. If not, requires full citation. Text: {{text}}

incorrect: Id. at 100. [case not in last 5 footnotes]

error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Full citation required - not cited in last 5 footnotes per RB 10.9

rules.title: When a Reporter Has Not Yet Been Published
rules.full_text: If a case has been decided but a reporter has not yet been published, cite to Westlaw (“WL”) or Lexis (“Lexus”), if available, rather than just the case name and docket number. See BB 10.8.1(c).

error_types.name: Case citation error - When a Reporter Has Not Yet Been Published
error_types.description: See RB 10.10 - When a Reporter Has Not Yet Been Published
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 10.10: When a Reporter Has Not Yet Been Published. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Check RB 10.10 - When a Reporter Has Not Yet Been Published

rules.title: Preferred Sources for Unreported Cases
rules.full_text:
Always use free sources in lieu of database citation strings for cases when possible. For example, a citation to the Supreme Court’s 2021 OSHA vaccine mandate decision should be: Nat’l Fed’n of Indep. Bus. v. Dep’t of Labor, Occupational Safety & Health Admin., No. 21A244, 595 U.S. ___ (Jan. 13, 2022) (per curiam), https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/21pdf/21a244_hgci.pdf.

Conversely, avoid Westlaw citations if a case is available for free elsewhere. If a case is available on SCOTUSblog, or from a news organization, link to that version rather than a Westlaw version (so long as the version is clearly the same document). Do not use “2022 WL . . .” if a case was decided in 2022. Instead, find an official version (see RB 11.1). For newly decided cases, this can be an official PDF if one is available (as in the vaccine mandate case above) or the website of a credible news outlet or law professor. Avoid SSRN, though, unless no other source is available.

Similarly, avoid “slip op.” or “manuscript” parentheticals (see BB 10.8.1(a)) if an alternate source is available. Those signals are intended to indicate that a source is temporarily unavailable in an official reporter, but if a free source is available, the more useful parenthetical is a URL.

error_types.name: Case citation error - Preferred Sources for Unreported Cases
error_types.description: See RB 10.11 - Preferred Sources for Unreported Cases
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 10.11: Preferred Sources for Unreported Cases. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Check RB 10.11 - Preferred Sources for Unreported Cases

rules.title: Docket Numbers in Federal Cases
rules.full_text:
When citing federal cases, include docket numbers for: (1) unpublished cases, or (2) cases from 1880 or earlier (even if published). For example: Marbury v. Madison, No. 000 (U.S. Feb. 11, 1803).

If you see a docket number in a citation, check whether these criteria are satisfied. If not, delete it.

See BB 10.8.1(g); BB 10.8.1(a).

error_types.name: Case citation error - Docket Numbers in Federal Cases
error_types.description: See RB 10.12 - Docket Numbers in Federal Cases
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 10.12: Docket Numbers in Federal Cases. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Check RB 10.12 - Docket Numbers in Federal Cases

rules.title: Docket Numbers for Consolidated Cases
rules.full_text:
When citing consolidated cases, include the docket number only for the case that the author is referencing. Do not include the docket numbers of the other consolidated cases.

See BB 10.8.1(g).

error_types.name: Case citation error - Docket Numbers for Consolidated Cases
error_types.description: See RB 10.13 - Docket Numbers for Consolidated Cases
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 10.13: Docket Numbers for Consolidated Cases. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Check RB 10.13 - Docket Numbers for Consolidated Cases

rules.title: Short Forms for Early Reporters
rules.full_text:
For early Supreme Court reporters that have multiple volumes for a single reporter (e.g., 1 Cranch, 2 Cranch, etc.), include the volume number in the short form. For example: “8 U.S. (4 Cranch) 62, 64 (1807)” becomes “4 Cranch at 64”.

See BB 10.9.

error_types.name: Case citation error - Short Forms for Early Reporters
error_types.description: See RB 10.14 - Short Forms for Early Reporters
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 10.14: Short Forms for Early Reporters. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Check RB 10.14 - Short Forms for Early Reporters

rules.title: Public Domain
rules.full_text:
If a state has implemented a public-domain citation format, SLR uses that format instead of regional reporter citations. (If a public-domain citation is available, include parenthetical information only if it is needed to understand the citation.)

See BB 10.3.3.

error_types.name: Case citation error - Public Domain
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 10.15: Public Domain. Text: {{text}}

rules.title: Signals Used as Verbs
rules.full_text: When a signal like “see” or “cf.” is used as a verb (e.g., “this analysis sees the world as zero-sum”), italicize it (as you would a signal in a citation sentence) to avoid confusion. So: “this analysis sees the world as zero-sum.” Note that this rule applies only when the word functions as a verb. If the word is used in another context (e.g., “this trend could see some effects”), do not italicize it. See BB 1.2.

error_types.name: Case citation error - Signals Used as Verbs
error_types.description: See RB 10.16 - Signals Used as Verbs
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 10.16: Signals Used as Verbs. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Check RB 10.16 - Signals Used as Verbs

rules.title: Subsequent History Phrases Involving Remand
rules.full_text: When adding a subsequent history phrase indicating a remand, SLR includes both the first and second remands (contrary to BB 10.7.1(d)). For example, “rev’d and remanded, then aff’d in relevant part, 999 F.3d 123 (2023) (per curiam)”. The Bluebook says to omit the first remand, but SLR includes it.

error_types.name: Case citation error - Subsequent History Phrases Involving Remand
error_types.description: See RB 10.17 - Subsequent History Phrases Involving Remand
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 10.17: Subsequent History Phrases Involving Remand. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Check RB 10.17 - Subsequent History Phrases Involving Remand

rules.title: Document Numbers in Federal Cases
rules.full_text:
When citing federal cases, do not include document numbers in citations unless they are needed to locate the source (for instance, in certain court filings that are only available on PACER). In most cases, a docket number and date is sufficient.

For example, do not cite a complaint as “Complaint at 5, No. 12 (D. Or. Jan. 1, 2021), ECF No. 33” unless that complaint cannot otherwise be found without the ECF number.

See BB 10.8.3; BB 7.3.2.

error_types.name: Case citation error - Document Numbers in Federal Cases
error_types.description: See RB 10.18 - Document Numbers in Federal Cases
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 10.18: Document Numbers in Federal Cases. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Check RB 10.18 - Document Numbers in Federal Cases

rules.title: Official Version of the U.S. Constitution
rules.full_text:
SLR’s official source for the U.S. Constitution is the National Archives version:

• Constitution: https://www.archives.gov/founding-docs/constitution-transcript

Do not cite the Constitution as “U.S. CONST.” (i.e., not to the printed edition); just write out the part or amendment without “U.S. CONST.” in front.

See RB 8.1.

error_types.name: Official Version of the U.S. Constitution violation
error_types.description: See RB 11.1: Official Version of the U.S. Constitution
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 11.1: Official Version of the U.S. Constitution. Key requirements: prohibited action. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Verify compliance with RB 11.1: Official Version of the U.S. Constitution

error_types.name: Official Version of the U.S. Constitution - formatting error
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check formatting compliance with RB 11.1. Text: {{text}}

error_types.name: Official Version of the U.S. Constitution - consistency error
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check for consistent application of RB 11.1 throughout document. Text: {{text}}

rules.title: Dates for the United States Code
rules.full_text:
Whenever the author cites a statute (including the U.S. Code), ensure that the date cited is the current published version of the code.

This means that for the next several years, citations to the U.S. Code should reference the 2018 edition (the most recent published set). Authors often cite the code as “U.S.C. (2018)” or “U.S.C. (2019)” (or 2020, 2021, 2022), but if that code title hasn’t yet been published in a 2021 volume, we have to change it to 2018. You may need to check the Office of Law Revision Counsel’s site to see which titles have been published.

If the 2021 volumes are published during the editing process, you may have to update the year in citations accordingly.

See BB 12.3.2; BB 12.8.2.

error_types.name: Wrong U.S.C. year
error_types.description: U.S.C. citation uses wrong year - should use most recent published edition
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check if U.S.C. citation uses current published edition year (currently 2018). Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Update U.S.C. year to current published edition per RB 12.1

rules.title: State Statutes
rules.full_text:
Include the publisher name for state statutes in citations only if it is needed to identify the version of the code being cited (as in an official code vs. an unofficial code). Do not include a publisher name if it isn’t needed for identification, even if the Bluebook (BB 12.3.1) suggests doing so.

See BB 12.3.1.

error_types.name: Statute citation error - State Statutes
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 12.2: State Statutes. Text: {{text}}

rules.title: Short Forms for Statutes
rules.full_text: Per BB 12.10, short-form citations can use a section symbol followed by the section number (and no “id.” or “supra”). But avoid using those short forms if the statute has not appeared in one of the previous five footnotes. If there is any ambiguity about what statute is being referenced, either use a full cite or use “id.” if appropriate.

error_types.name: Statute citation error - Short Forms for Statutes
error_types.description: See RB 12.3 - Short Forms for Statutes
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 12.3: Short Forms for Statutes. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Check RB 12.3 - Short Forms for Statutes

rules.title: Identical Digits for Statutes
rules.full_text:
When a statutory section number includes an identical repeated digit separated only by punctuation (e.g., 42 U.S.C. § 1490dd), include only one “section” symbol and put a comma between the identical digits.

So, write “42 U.S.C. § 1490, dd” (not “§§ 1490dd”). See BB 3.3. Do the same thing if the identical digits are separated by a hyphen (e.g., write “§ 4001-03” instead of “§§ 4001-03”).

error_types.name: Statute citation error - Identical Digits for Statutes
error_types.description: See RB 12.4 - Identical Digits for Statutes
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 12.4: Identical Digits for Statutes. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Check RB 12.4 - Identical Digits for Statutes

rules.title: Citing the Internal Revenue Code
rules.full_text:
Cite the Internal Revenue Code by title and section only. Do not include “I.R.C.” at the beginning of the citation. For example, “26 U.S.C. § 1” (not “I.R.C. § 1”).

See BB 12.9.1.

error_types.name: Statute citation error - Citing the Internal Revenue Code
error_types.description: See RB 12.5 - Citing the Internal Revenue Code
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 12.5: Citing the Internal Revenue Code. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Check RB 12.5 - Citing the Internal Revenue Code

rules.title: Abbreviating Uniform Statutes
rules.full_text:
Always use the abbreviation “Unif.” for citations to uniform laws or acts (e.g., Unif. Probate Code, Unif. Interstate Family Support Act). Do not write out “Uniform” even if the Bluebook suggests doing so in a particular context.

See BB 12.9.4.

error_types.name: Statute citation error - Abbreviating Uniform Statutes
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 12.6: Abbreviating Uniform Statutes. Text: {{text}}

rules.title: Abbreviating Local Statutes or Ordinances
rules.full_text:
Unless an abbreviation is commonly used, write out the full name for local statutes (e.g., San Francisco Administrative Code). That is, don’t try to make abbreviations like “S.F. Admin. Code” happen.

See BB 12.8.3.

error_types.name: Statute citation error - Abbreviating Local Statutes or Ordinances
error_types.description: See RB 12.7 - Abbreviating Local Statutes or Ordinances
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 12.7: Abbreviating Local Statutes or Ordinances. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Check RB 12.7 - Abbreviating Local Statutes or Ordinances

rules.title: Codification Information for Session Laws
rules.full_text:
Citations to session laws should generally include any codification information if available (e.g., “Pub. L. No. 111-203, 124 Stat. 1376, 1480 (2010) (codified as amended at 15 U.S.C. § 78o–10 (2018))”). Often, the author will provide a session law citation but not codification information; in that case, you should add it.

But be sure to double-check whether a codification exists, and don’t add a parenthetical if it isn’t needed (e.g., if the act was never codified, or if the act is only pertinent as a session law rather than as part of a codified title). If you have any doubt as to whether you should pull a codified statute, consult with your SE and your primary ME. If an author uses “Act of [Date]” or “[Name] Act” in a citation, chances are that you do.

error_types.name: Statute citation error - Codification Information for Session Laws
error_types.description: See RB 12.8 - Codification Information for Session Laws
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 12.8: Codification Information for Session Laws. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Check RB 12.8 - Codification Information for Session Laws

rules.title: Federal Register Dates
rules.full_text:
For sources in the Federal Register, always include a parenthetical with the full date.

See BB 14.2.

error_types.name: Federal Register Dates violation
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 14.1: Federal Register Dates. Key requirements: required action. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Verify compliance with RB 14.1: Federal Register Dates

rules.title: FTC Filings
rules.full_text:
For Federal Trade Commission filings, include “FTC” in front of “File No.” in citations, as in “FTC File No. 192-3000”. This is a departure from BB 14.2(d), which would omit “FTC” and simply use “File No.” (because the commission is already named).

See BB 14.2(d).

error_types.name: FTC Filings violation
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 14.2: FTC Filings. Key requirements: see rule text. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Verify compliance with RB 14.2: FTC Filings

error_types.name: FTC Filings - formatting error
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check formatting compliance with RB 14.2. Text: {{text}}

error_types.name: FTC Filings - consistency error
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check for consistent application of RB 14.2 throughout document. Text: {{text}}

rules.title: SEC Filings
rules.full_text:
For Securities and Exchange Commission filings, include “SEC” in front of form names when they are used in citations. For example, “SEC Form 10-K” rather than “Form 10-K”. Also, include the year of the filing at the end of the citation. This is a departure from BB 14.3, which would omit “SEC” and the year (because the commission is already named and the year can be inferred from context).

See BB 14.3.

error_types.name: SEC Filings violation
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 14.3: SEC Filings. Key requirements: see rule text. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Verify compliance with RB 14.3: SEC Filings

error_types.name: SEC Filings - formatting error
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check formatting compliance with RB 14.3. Text: {{text}}

error_types.name: SEC Filings - consistency error
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check for consistent application of RB 14.3 throughout document. Text: {{text}}

rules.title: Et al.
rules.section: BOOKS, REPORTS, AND OTHER NONPERIODIC MATERIALS
rules.full_text:
When listing authors, SLR uses “et al.” for four or more authors (i.e., list all authors if there are three or fewer). This is a departure from BB 15.1, which lists all authors if there are up to three, but only the first author’s name if there are two. For SLR, go ahead and list both authors if there are two.

See BB 15.1.

error_types.name: Et al. with 3 or fewer authors
error_types.description: Using 'et al.' when 3 or fewer authors (should list all)
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check author count. SLR uses 'et al.' only for 4+ authors. With 2-3 authors, list all. Text: {{text}}

incorrect: John Doe et al., BOOK TITLE (2020).
correct: John Doe, Jane Smith & Bob Jones, BOOK TITLE (2020).

error_types.comment_template: [AA:] List all authors (3 or fewer) per RB 15.1

rules.title: Subtitles
rules.section: BOOKS, REPORTS, AND OTHER NONPERIODIC MATERIALS
rules.full_text:
In the titles of works, always include subtitles after a colon, even if the source itself omits the subtitle on the title page or cover. This applies especially to books.

See BB 15.4(d).

error_types.name: Book citation error - Subtitles
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 15.2: Subtitles. Text: {{text}}

rules.title: Reports with Serial Numbers
rules.section: BOOKS, REPORTS, AND OTHER NONPERIODIC MATERIALS
rules.full_text:
If a report has a serial number, include it in the citation. For example, “S. REP. NO. 111-5”. See BB 15.3; BB 13.4.

If a report has multiple parts that were published in different years, indicate that with a span. For example, “1 NAT’L RES. COUNCIL, REPORT NAME 1 (2019) (2 vols.); 2 id. (2020)”. See BB 15.4(d).

error_types.name: Book citation error - Reports with Serial Numbers
error_types.description: See RB 15.3 - Reports with Serial Numbers
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 15.3: Reports with Serial Numbers. Text: {{text}}
error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Check RB 15.3 - Reports with Serial Numbers

rules.title: Online Treatises
rules.section: BOOKS, REPORTS, AND OTHER NONPERIODIC MATERIALS
rules.full_text:
For treatises that have an online version, include the online publisher in citations. Specifically, if a treatise is published online on Lexis or Westlaw (or elsewhere), include “Lexis” or “Westlaw” in italics as the publisher name, in the parenthetical at the end of the cite. You can also include a URL in the parenthetical instead of “Lexis” or “Westlaw”.

See BB 15.9(c).

error_types.name: Book citation error - Online Treatises
error_types.gpt_validation_prompt: Check compliance with RB 15.4: Online Treatises. Text: {{text}}

rules.title: Preferred Versions of Common Works and Special Citation Forms
rules.section: BOOKS, REPORTS, AND OTHER NONPERIODIC MATERIALS
rules.full_text:
Below are special rules SLR follows for certain commonly cited works. They are often similar to Bluebook rules but with a twist or additional nuance (or they are otherwise easily overlooked by editors). If a piece you are editing cites one of these works or types of sources, be sure to follow these rules.
• American Law Reports: When citing a proposition supported by multiple ALR entries, list multiple ALR entries in the same parenthetical with semicolons between them, even if published decades apart. (This is a departure from the Bluebook’s normal rule for related authorities, where sources are separated by semicolons only if they were published within twenty years.)
• Black’s Law Dictionary: Don’t include the edition number; instead, include the year that the edition was published in the parenthetical.
• Federalist papers: SLR’s official version is compiled in Ralph Ketcham’s The Anti-Federalist Papers and the Constitutional Convention Debates (1986). Cite that version for any references to Federalist essays (e.g., THE FEDERALIST NO. 10). But if an author includes a pinpoint cite, use the page number from the relevant Federalist essay as printed in Ketcham’s volume (even if the essay numbering is different).
• Foreign Affairs Federalist / Pacificus-Helvidius debates: SLR’s official version is compiled in JAMES MADISON & ALEXANDER HAMILTON, THE PACIFICUS-HELVIDIUS DEBATES OF 1793–1794 (Morton J. Frisch ed., 2007).
• The Federalist (anti-federalist): For the anti-federalist Federal Farmer letters, SLR’s official version is compiled in ESSAYS OF THE CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION (Paul Leicester Ford ed., 1892). We often cite these letters as Federal Farmer letters, despite their name.
• U.N. Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS): SLR’s official source is the United Nations website, which contains the final official version of the convention in PDF form. If in doubt about which version of a work to use, leave an [SE:] Comment. See BB 15.7; BB 21.5.

error_types.description: Not using SLR-preferred edition (see RB 15.5 list)

correct: THE FEDERALIST NO. 10, in THE ANTI-FEDERALIST PAPERS (Ralph Ketcham ed., 1986).

rules.title: Works in a Collection
rules.section: BOOKS, REPORTS, AND OTHER NONPERIODIC MATERIALS
rules.full_text:
When citing a work contained in a larger collection (e.g., an essay or excerpt in a book-length collection or textbook), SLR’s preference is to cite the smaller work and then the larger work. But if the author cites to the larger work as a whole, that’s fine.

For example:

Right: Jane Doe, Essay Title, in BOOK TITLE 1, 4 (John Doe ed., 2024).

OK: BOOK TITLE 1, 4 (John Doe ed., 2024).

error_types.comment_template: [AA:] Check RB 15.6 - Works in a Collection

rules.title: Nonconsecutively Paginated Journals and Magazines
rules.full_text: When citing to a nonconsecutively paginated journal, magazine, or newspaper (as opposed to consecutively paginated law reviews), do not list the volume number if one exists. Instead, list the date followed by the publication name, as with newspaper citations. For example, the Stanford Magazine is a quarterly alumni magazine with nonconsecutive pagination, and you should not include volume/issue numbers in its citations; just treat it like a newspaper. See BB 16.6(d); BB 16.3.5.

rules.title: Open-Access Journals and Certain Nonconsecutively Paginated Journals
rules.full_text:
Some law journals are “open access” and have electronic articles that are assigned an article number (e.g., 2022 U. CHI. L. REV. ONLINE 1) instead of a page number. Others are nonconsecutively paginated but have PDF page numbers that look like consecutively paginated pages. For any of those, you should use the article number (or first page number) in the citation but also include a URL (or a perma link if needed) at the end of the citation. The University of Chicago Law Review Online is one example; the Harvard National Security Journal is another (its pages look like 1–30 but that’s only within each article’s individual PDF). Other examples include University of Pennsylvania Law Review Online, California Law Review Online, etc.

If in doubt, leave an [SE:] Comment.

See BB 16.8; BB 16.6(d).

rules.title: Online Versions of Newspaper or Magazine Articles
rules.full_text:
For newspapers or magazines that have both a print and an online version, cite the version that the author actually used. If an author cites the online version but your sourcepull leads you to the print version, you do not need to change the citation to print; you can just cite the online version (though you may wish to leave an [SE:] Comment noting the existence of a print version). Likewise, if an author cites a print version but you find only the online version, just cite the print version as if you had seen it in print.

See BB 16.6(e).

rules.title: Special Reports in Newspapers
rules.full_text:
If a citation is to a special report or series in a newspaper (e.g., the New York Times’s “Reckoning” series about Harvey Weinstein, or the Washington Post’s “Opioids” series), include the series name in the citation (in italics, after the newspaper name). For example:

Alan Schwarz, The Talented Mr. Strasburg, N.Y. TIMES (The Reckoning), Sept. 5, 2023, https://perma.cc/XXXX-YYYY.

See BB 16.6.4(a).

rules.title: Citing Abstracts
rules.full_text:
If an author cites an abstract (for example, an abstract on SSRN or on the AEA website for an economics article), try to find the underlying paper and cite that instead. If you cannot find a non-abstract source, cite the abstract the same way you would a full article, but add “(abstract)” at the end of the parenthetical. For example: “[article info], (Aug. 2023) (abstract).”

See BB 16.7.3.

rules.title: Checking for Special Designations
rules.full_text:
Always double-check whether any component of the volume, issue, or date needs to be included for a periodical citation. For example, if a piece is in a supplement, you may need to add a “Supp.” designation. Or if a periodical is organized by season rather than month, you may need to add that (e.g., “Fall 2023”). If an issue is a special symposium issue, you may need to add that (e.g., “Symposium Issue”). Authors often leave out those designations, so you should keep an eye out for them.

See BB 16.4; BB 16.5.

rules.title: SSRN Publications
rules.full_text:
If an author cites a publication that is on SSRN, check whether it has been published elsewhere. If it has, cite to the published version instead. If it has not, include a parenthetical at the end of the citation indicating “manuscript at X”, where X is the page on the PDF that the author is citing (or, if no pincite, the total number of pages preceded by “at”). Add a date if available.

For example: “[author info], (Mar. 2022) (manuscript at 15, SSRN), http://ssrn.com/abstract=1234567.” Or if a pincite is given: “at 15”.

See BB 17.1.1.

rules.title: URLs
rules.full_text: All citations to internet sources should include a URL unless it is unnecessary (e.g., the citation is to a print source or a video as described below). All links should be provided in their full, direct (not hyperlinked) form (and should be preserved as per [SLR’s perma policy]). See BB 18.2.

rules.title: Avoiding Repetitious Author Names or Page Titles
rules.full_text:
If citing a web page or report where the page title repeats the author’s name or the organization name (e.g., an “about” page listing a person’s bio information or a PDF report listing an organization as the author and again in the title), you can shorten the title of the source by omitting the repetitious part.

For example, if the citation is to an About Us page for an organization, you might use just the organization name as the main page title if that seems more logical and easier to read. Or if a report’s title repeats the organization’s name, you might shorten the title to exclude the repetition. Always ensure that the shortened title still clearly identifies the source.

If unsure whether to shorten a title, you can leave an [SE:] Comment for guidance.

rules.title: Omitting Words in Main Page Titles
rules.full_text:
For web page titles that include generic terms like “Home” or the site’s name as part of the main page title, you may omit those if they are not needed for clarity. For example, if a homepage title is “XYZ Organization – Home”, you can just use “XYZ Organization” as the title in the citation.

However, be careful not to remove any unique or necessary part of the title. Only omit parts that are clearly extraneous.

See BB 18.2.3.

rules.title: Dates and Times
rules.full_text:
Include a timestamp in the date parenthetical of an internet source only if the source itself is updated multiple times a day and listing a time is necessary to identify the version referenced. Otherwise, just include the date. If a source shows a time but the content is not rapidly updated, you can usually omit the time from the citation.

If including a time, use the time zone given or convert to a standard time zone (like ET) if needed, and express it in a consistent format (e.g., “Sept. 5, 2023, 9:30 PM ET”).

See BB 18.2.2(a).

rules.title: Parallel Citations to Internet Sources
rules.full_text:
If a source is available in multiple formats (e.g., an online article with an accompanying PDF), you generally do not need to provide parallel citations or links to both versions. Cite the version the author used or that is easier for readers to access. If the versions are identical in content, one citation is sufficient.

However, if the different formats contain different information or if it's important to note the existence of another format (such as an archived PDF version), you can include a parenthetical or explanatory phrase.

See BB 18.2.2; BB 18.7.2.

rules.title: Location Parentheticals for Websites
rules.full_text:
If an online source is part of a website that has sections or a hierarchy, you can include that information parenthetically to clarify where on the site the content is located. For example, a press release might be under a “News” section; you could cite it as: [Title], [Site Name] (Nov. 1, 2023) (press release).

Only add such parentheticals if they help clarify the nature or context of the source.

See BB 18.7.3.

rules.title: Miscellaneous Documents in PDF Form
rules.full_text:
For miscellaneous PDF documents that are not formally published elsewhere (e.g., an unofficial PDF report or a scanned letter), treat them as internet sources. Provide a descriptive title if needed and the URL. If they have an author and date, include those as you would for an internet source.

For example, a scanned letter titled “Letter from X to Y” (Oct. 3, 2020), could be cited with that title, date, and a URL to the PDF.

Ensure that the citation makes clear what the document is, especially if it's not obvious from the title.

See BB 18.1; BB 17.1.3.

rules.title: Dates for Online PDFs
rules.full_text:
When citing an online PDF, use the date on the document itself (if available) rather than the date of download or the date the website lists it (unless the latter is the only date available). For example, if a PDF report is dated June 2022 but the site says “posted Aug. 2022”, use June 2022 in the citation.

If a document is undated, use the date the content was last modified or accessed, as per Bluebook rules, and indicate accordingly (e.g., “last modified Mar. 3, 2023” or “accessed Mar. 3, 2023”).

See BB 18.2.2(b).

rules.title: Movies
rules.full_text: Citations to movies or films should generally include the year of release and the director (in a parenthetical). For example: Movie Title (Director Name dir., 2020). If referencing a specific part of a movie (like a scene or a timestamp), you can include a timestamp in a parenthetical (e.g., at 01:23:45). Italicize movie titles as per usual rule for large works. See BB 18.7.3; BB 14.7.

rules.title: Names in Treaty Titles
rules.full_text:
Where the title of a treaty includes the names of the parties to the treaty, omit that portion from the title, unless doing so would shorten the treaty name to “Treaty” or otherwise render it too generic. Essentially, focus on the substantive part of the treaty’s title rather than the listing of parties in the title.

For example, if a treaty is titled “Treaty between the Government of X and the Government of Y on Cooperation in Z”, you can shorten it to “Treaty on Cooperation in Z”.

See BB 21.4.5.

rules.title: Spelling
rules.full_text:
If an alternate but still correct spelling of a word appears in a piece (e.g., “advisor” vs. “adviser”), default to the spelling listed in Merriam-Webster unless there’s a good reason to retain the alternate spelling. However, be cautious when it comes to proper nouns or titles where the spelling is part of an official name.

In general, do not Americanize or Britishize the spelling of quotations—keep them as in the original.

See CMOS 7.1; CMOS 7.2.

rules.title: Plurals
rules.full_text:
For words that have two plural forms (e.g., “appendixes” vs. “appendices”), use the form listed as the primary variant in Merriam-Webster. If both forms are listed equally, use one consistently throughout the piece.

For words ending in “-us” that have a plural “-i” (like “fungus” vs. “fungi”), use the English plural “-uses” unless the context demands the Latin form.

See CMOS 7.6.

rules.title: Hyphenation
rules.full_text:
Follow Merriam-Webster for whether a compound is hyphenated, one word, or two words. If Merriam-Webster lists multiple forms (hyphenated vs. closed), use the first-listed form.

However, avoid unnecessary hyphenation in adverbial phrases (for example, do not hyphenate “widely used” as it is clear without a hyphen).

See CMOS 7.89 (guidelines on hyphenation).

rules.title: Quotation Marks and Apostrophes
rules.full_text:
Use smart quotes (curly quotes) for quotations and apostrophes, not straight quotes or primes. Ensure that any quotation marks or apostrophes in the text appear as proper typographic marks (e.g., “ ” and ‘ ’, not " " or ' '). This often requires checking for instances where a word like “husky’s” might mistakenly use a straight apostrophe instead of a curly one.

Additionally, be mindful of the distinction between an apostrophe and a single opening quote — these can look similar but face different directions in typography.

See CMOS 13.1–13.7.

rules.title: Commas
rules.full_text:
Use the serial comma (Oxford comma) in lists of three or more items. Additionally, ensure that comma usage follows standard grammar rules (e.g., use a comma before a conjunction in a compound sentence, after introductory phrases, etc.).

Do not use a comma between a subject and verb or between a verb and object unnecessarily. For instance, avoid “The result, was surprising.”

If an author has a stylistic comma (e.g., in a certain phrasing for effect), usually leave it unless it creates confusion or is grammatically incorrect.

See CMOS 6.16–6.21.

rules.title: Hyphens and Dashes
rules.full_text:
Use hyphens (-) for hyphenating words (e.g., “well-known”). Use en dashes (–) for ranges (e.g., “2019–2020”) and relationships (e.g., “New York–London flight”). Use em dashes (—) for breaks in thought or parenthetical statements—like this.

Make sure not to confuse hyphens with en dashes in number ranges (the latter should be longer). Also, do not put spaces around em dashes.

See CMOS 6.75–6.89.

rules.title: The One-Space Rule
rules.full_text:
Use only one space after a period (or other terminal punctuation) at the end of a sentence. Do not use two spaces, even if the author does; this should be standardized to one space throughout the piece.

The same rule applies to colons — use one space after a colon (unless in a citation or ratio, where formatting rules may differ).

This is a global find-and-replace job, but be careful not to alter intentional spacing in indented text or fixed-width formats.

See CMOS 6.7.

rules.title: Nonbreaking Spaces
rules.full_text:
Insert a nonbreaking space (Option+Space on a Mac; Ctrl+Shift+Space on a PC) between a symbol and its corresponding numeral. This is done so that a line break will not separate, for instance, “§ 1983” into the section symbol on one line and the number on the next, or “$ 50” from the number.

Also consider using nonbreaking spaces in other contexts, such as between “U.S.” and “§” or between an initial and a last name (if an initial is used).

Nonbreaking hyphens can also be used in citation spans (to avoid breaks in “2015–2017” for instance).

This is more of a technical typesetting rule; implement it where possible, but it may not always be visible in word processors.

See CMOS 6.36.

rules.title: Dates and Date Ranges
rules.full_text:
Retain all digits when giving a range of years (for example, “1993–1998,” not “1993–98”).

When referring to decades, do not insert an apostrophe (for example, “1780s,” not “1780’s”). Additionally, if abbreviating a decade, use an apostrophe to indicate omitted numerals (e.g., the ’80s for 1980s).

Spell out months in textual discussions. In citations, follow Bluebook rules (which usually abbreviate longer month names).

See CMOS 9.3; BB 12.1.

rules.title: Capital Letter After a Colon
rules.full_text:
In general, do not capitalize the first word after a colon unless it starts an independent clause or is a proper noun. For instance, “The rule is clear: do not capitalize after a colon in a fragment.” But: “Consider the following: The Results Were Significant.”

Some styles differ on this; SLR follows the Chicago Manual here.

See CMOS 6.63.

rules.title: Doctrine of Patently Asinine Results
rules.full_text:
Be on the lookout for instances where blind application of a rule yields a patently asinine result. The “Doctrine of Patently Asinine Results” is an SLR maxim that allows deviation from any rule when following the rule would lead to a clearly absurd outcome. In other words, use common sense: if adhering strictly to a rule makes a sentence or citation look ridiculous or confusing, find a sensible alternative.

Always consult with your SE if you think a situation merits invoking this doctrine; it’s better not to unilaterally decide something is an exception without confirmation.

This doctrine is more of a guiding principle than a formal rule—an editor’s intuition to maintain readability and clarity above strict conformity when necessary.
